title: Between 6 December and 31 December 2017, will there be an attack on the drone base near Agadez, Niger?
preds: No, because not only is it too late, but it is unlikely due to regional issues.
It's the 31st... hasn't happened yet (that I know of)
Too many drones in the air
Ratio of difficulty-to-attack to geopolitical impact is low.  However, there are many extreme groups nearby.

Lack of preparation. Also, after multiple years of construction American milatary presence is common in the are as such I'd expect a higher level of defenses that would deter small scale attacks. The remote location of the base indicates that a larger scale attack would also prove difficult to execute.
Very secure location, no attack yet, and only 1 day of time frame remaining.

The higher occurrence of attacks on (Coptic) Christians , albeit not related to niger per se, but the anti west sentiment could culminate to an attack on the traditionally western holidays that fall between those dates.
Havenâ€™t heard of any attacks lately
it is highly secure if its location is even accurate and known
Only 1 day left for it to happen
It is unlikely, given this late date. And while the presence of a drone base may be a compelling target to the extremists, it also has some deterrent effects.
Even though it's already 30 December, it's possible that such an attack might take place, however, I don't believe it's an immediate target

There's 1/4 of a chance it could happen, but that date is rapidly approaching so I would estimate it likelier to happen after Jan 1, 2018. The reason I say it's somewhat likely prior to then is due to the Italian troops moving into Niger (over 400) to "stem migrant flow" that could provoke extremists into action rather quickly.
Limited time to plan and prepare, NYE holiday probably more likely to distract from execution than provide cover
Attacks on US bases are extremely rare.

Looking at historical attacks on the base seems to suggest that there is a 0.21% chance on any given day that terrorists will attack the base. 3 days remaining suggests there's a less than 1% chance of an attack occurring in the remaining three days of the year.
terrorists  are  too  scared  to  attack  a  military  target,

This prediction is based on the number of days left in the prediction span of time, the operational status of the base, and knowledge (or lack thereof) about the base by local residents. More damage would be done if the potential sabatoteurs waited until the base was fully operational to make an attack.

Hostile area where attacks have occurred in last few months but an attack on a well guarded airbase would probably need to be a bigger better planned and lower frequency event. Maybe 1-2 times a year... 
And there's only 2 days left in the year so 1% (i.e. 1 attack every 200 days) seems reasonable.
Violent extremists in Niger don't have the capacity to attack a U.S. installation.

Based on a quick overview, part of the concern is the people joining terrorist groups for livelihood. The probability of an uprising/attack on the base from people within the country is small because they are not organized enough to do anything. Don't see any reason for an attack from outside the country within the next 2 to 3 days unless there had been talks by them of doing it and I have not read about it.

The base is a likely target due to its proximity to extremist factions. Only slightly noir than 50/50 chance as it is a heavily guarded base, but a likely target attempt due to local opinions of base's actions

It is possible, due to Islamic threats against US outposts recently. However, I think it isn't likely in the next couple of days. The base will be alerted to any increased threats if an attack was going to be attempted in the next few days.
"Festival de l'Aïr" (27–29 December): Music and arts festival at Iférouane ;
I dont think the base will come under attack within the next 3 days. 1% because you never know.
unlikely in the next few days
December is almost over at this point. Niger and the US have stake in protecting the base.
seems the odds are against this happening and there probably is thourough security.
The year is so close to being done not this year
Current on going Drone operations in the area will always make the area a target.
Forecast based solely upon the fact that it is now 28/12/17 and no attack thus far.
-Few days remaining in the forecast period;
It is very close to 31 December.
Boko Haram is not likely to sacrifice troops attacking a fortified position. They are more likely to ambush supply convoys
Donâ€™t see it as anything of strategic importance

After the loss of U.S. special forces' lives in Africa this year, security will be heavy enough to discourage any attacks. Also, there is only 4 days left in the time period & nothing has happened as of today.

Despite the fact that the insurgents would want to vanquish any of their enemies and show force to drive out international military assets they understand that this would be a large provocation and increase the amount of African Union Soldiers as well as International military assets that would be inundating the region therefore stopping their efforts of growing as an insurgency in Niger. There is still some chance because not all attacks are always made with logic there for high alert and continued vigilance should be implemented.

Spotty intelligence gathering ability in this area. The recent death of US Special Forces (will bolster the extremist's confidence). Al-Qaeda has influence in the area and the anniversary of the Aden bombing is December 29. Low probability @ 5% because of the arrest of clan leaders involved in the delaying tactic that resulted in the deaths of US Special Forces has an impact on the extremist's communication in that area.

2018 odds increase as more people discover the base
Base is under construction, so air traffic is low
Once Air traffic increase the chance of an attack in 2018 will increase.
Concerns raised by local residents are not by themselves an indicator that the base will be the target of an attack.
Just a guess. It could always happen in that area but don't predict any particular reason there should be one.
Forced to round down from 1%. Assume there is a 12% chance of a attack in a year. Then each day is .031% times five days is 0.16%
A bit of a guess. It just feels increasingly unstable there.
Seems unlikely based on few remaining days in time range and the lack of reported recent attacks.
Current operations and the urgency of ending, or minimizing, terrorism. This administration has given more latitude to commanders in the field to make those decisions.
It may not be a violent attack but recon that leads to an attack is part of the attack.

I feel it is doubtful they will strike given their lack of organization presently; that being said, US forces should still remain viligant and the possibility is still not zero: A "lone wolf" unorganized extremist who is merely a sympathizer may try something; This possibility is negligible although it is not zero.

While it is likely an attack on the drone base is a strategy being considered by violent extremists in the region, it seems more likely that it would come a few months to a year down the line. The base appears to have been tested for defensive response by militants about a year and a half ago, which indicates it is certainly on their radar, however they may be waiting for a more opportunistic time to attack, such as when the base expansion nears completion or during the wet season around July. Conversely, the base may be considered a softer target on a holiday, so there may be slightly elevated probability of attack vs other days in December, but given the low daily probability of attack on a given day and the few days left in the time period in question, it is very unlikely we will see the attack in the next week. If anything, it is more likely we will see another defensive response test by a small group of militants as opposed to an assault on the base.
The drone based will not be completed until sometime in 2018.  Unlikely but not impossible at this time.

Nothing about US presence in the country has been particularly noxious by the recent running average.  If a raid can be scared off by lasers over a year ago, and no news has been produced about US action in the country since, then I don't think there is enough boldness in the militants there to risk direct US retaliation.

With the December holiday season that Americans practice, there could be a consensus among local militants that they may find the drone base of Agadez a choicer target due to an increase in distractions and the belief that such an action is improbable at this time.  A recent attack which left 4 U.S. service members killed has emboldened Islamic militants of the region.
Because the odds are greater for an attack during 2018 than for this one month.
Extremists don't like Christmas so it is a possible - albeit remote.

Fires will burn 
Targets will be soft
Why attack a drone base
When their loved ones are shopping

there are only 9 days until 12/31, but there will likely be some reprisal for the U.S. soldiers killed in Niger. It's near Christmas, so the military probably won't attack during this time, but might if they found a good enough target, and wanted the element of surprise.
violence against US assets in Niger has been relatively quiet recently
Little time left, low value target
Security of base makes it difficult to engage. Time left in challenge.
Number of days left in challenge. Security of base makes it difficult to engage.
An attack could occur at any time, but the probability of one is low in a given short span of time.
No active combat operations in Agadez at this point. It is unlikely that within less than a month, it will be attacked by enemy forces
ex military, interested in US international military operations

1.) Militants likely would choose a softer target. 2.) AQIM reads The Washington Post, too. 3.) Boko Haram commanders seek maximum impact via shock & awe. A drone base attack might reduce their losses, but it wouldn't hurt their main enemies: Christians & non-radical Muslims.
its a 4 way split with 1per more for attack
The definition of attack is broad. Attacks in Africa are chronically underestimated.
There was no change to my assessment.  Attacks against military compounds remain low.

There have been only a few isolated attacks recently from unknown perpetrators in central Nigeria.  Boko Haram is active in the north and east in very different terrain. 
     Nigeria is cracking down on the human smuggling routes, therefore there will be less of an opportunity to actually smuggle in radical terrorist. The population may be young , uneducated, unemployed and consequently vulnerable to islamist terrorists however if it remains more stable and less vulnerable to human trafficking it may become more secure in the long run with the continued involvement and intervention from u.s. civil affairs.
The abilities of the attackers and the technology of the defenders is so skewed in favor of the defenders it seems highly unlikely an attack will occur in the near future.

Given the flat terrain this base seems difficult to approach undetected. And not to come across as a terrorist elitist, but I'm not aware of groups in this region having successfully carried out such ambitious attacks. In addition, although I could not dig up supporting information, attacks on US military bases (excluding those in active war zones) seem rare. Finally, terrorist attacks are quite rare, period.

Niger gov't recently approved US use of armed UAVs, but out of Niamey, not Agadez. This opens potential for US military attacks in the 6-31 Dec window. However, UAV attacks in Horn of Africa are averaging +/-2 per month. So not likely that US would immediately engage. Also, not likely that  counter-attack would target Agadez if it was not the origin of the attack.

There are bigger and better targets for extremists, Concern that this might happen seems to be coming from locals, and is motivated by the well-known NIMBY phenomenon, rather than hard evidence of an impending attack.
Not  expected to open until sometime in 2018, according to the Washington Post.
US forces are in the process of moving their drone base to Agadez....which is to be completed by Jan 2018.... if any attack on the base, will be post the move to Agadez.
Focus for non-state actors has reverse shifted to North Africa and Sahel
Seems unlikely in the next few weeks.
this base is still u der construction-wont be operational till mid next year and a temporary base is being utilized till then
the drine base is mission critical and yherefore a improtabt target, but consequently it is defended in depth qith multiple ambush points.

Asymmetric responses to attacks from nonstate actors makes the use of this strategy by insurgents too costly.   Target preferences by nonstate actors must have a maximized utility where EU(c, b) > C(u, w).   Costs of weapons purchased, stolen or coerced from state stockpiles are valuable and have exponential human and material costs that are invaluable to nonstate actors; Preferenced choices where warfare is asymmetric and results in outcomes with significant strategic losses for nonstate or state actors is based on irrational decision making.   Nonstate actors, like all dictators, are rational in their their logic for survival.  Terror strategies often are used when nonstate actors engage in urban, metropolitan settings or rural environments where the collective action problem for insurgents ( nonstate actors) can be solved.  A military base with drone technology increases the difficulties to be solved in this CA problem.  Counterterror strategies contribute to uncertainties for nonstate actors, increasing the intensity of their CA problem.  Empirically, obstacles (barriers) decrease the success of nonstate actor attacks by a probability greater than 68%.

Although Taureg are returning from Lybia and ISIS/AQ fighters from Syria and Iraq may find their way to the Sahel, the chance of an attack is unlikely due to increased US, French, and Nigerien personnel and surveillance after the recent attack on US soldiers near border with Mali.
Seems super unlikely esp. in this time frame but not negligible.
Anything, one supposes, can happen, but this one seems unlikely.

The baseline for attacks over the past two years against US military compounds in Africa is very low.  While there are attacks in the area around Agadez, I doubt there is sufficient capacity for an assault.  Perhaps, artillery is a good strategy but not immediately.

"Humvees patrol this week along the perimeter of a $100 million U.S. drone base being built outside Agadez"
How can one attack something which does not yet exist?

In by opinion, the likelihood of such an attack on the Agadez drone base is doubtful.  Following the ambush of the SF team, I suspect that security will be enhanced around the base and surrounding area.
